importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the most recent update on the flooding disaster, indicating ongoing humanitarian and emergency response efforts in Mexico.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding event occurred in less than a week, showing the rapid escalation of the disaster and the urgent need for emergency response actions.

keyTakeAways: The death toll from flooding in central and southeastern Mexico has risen to at least 44, with Mexico’s El Universal reporting a higher figure of 48.

The flooding was caused by heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which affected five Mexican states: Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosí.
Specific fatalities include 18 in Veracruz, 16 in Hidalgo, 9 in Puebla, and 1 in Queretaro.
Dozens of people remain missing, and over 320,000 people have experienced power outages, with at least 16,000 homes damaged.
The Mexican government has mobilized the military for rescue operations and aid distribution, with President Claudia Sheinbaum stating, 'We will not leave anyone without support.'
Photos from the military show evacuations using life rafts, flooded homes, and rescue workers navigating through waist-high waters.
Mexico has faced unusually heavy rainfall this year, with Mexico City recording its rainiest June in over two decades.
The remnants of Tropical Rainstorm Raymond are expected to impact southern Baja California on Sunday, indicating continued weather-related risks.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Torrential rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond have triggered severe flooding and landslides across five central and southeastern Mexican states, including Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosí. The death toll has reached at least 44, with Mexico’s El Universal reporting 48 fatalities and dozens still missing. Over 320,000 people have lost power, and 16,000 homes have been damaged. The Mexican government has activated the military to carry out evacuations and deliver aid, with President Claudia Sheinbaum emphasizing that no one will be left without support. The event is linked to unusually heavy rainfall in Mexico this year, with Mexico City experiencing its rainiest June in over two decades, and the remnants of Raymond expected to impact southern Baja California shortly after.
title: Death toll from Mexico flooding rises to 44, dozens more missing
